Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Preparing to Teach Algebra: A Study of Teacher Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to study how secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs provide preservice teachers opportunities to develop knowledge for teaching algebra and address algebra expectations in state-level policies and their relatinship to the Common Core State Standards for mathematics (CCSSM). It is designed to answer two important research questions: (1) What opportunities do secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs provide to learn about algebra, algebra teaching, and issues in achieving equity in algebra learning? And (2) In what ways do secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs address the algebra, functions, and modeling standards and mathematical practices described in the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM)?

Mixed-methods will be employed in this research project, including developing, piloting, refining, and administering data collection instruments and protocols for a web-based large-scale national program survey, case studies of teacher preparation programs, and focus group interviews with student teachers. This project focuses on algebra, an important topic in mathematics education that has been described as both fundamental to learning advanced mathematics and a gatekeeper for success

There is no national survey about pre-service teachers' opportunities to develop knowledge for teaching algebra in the literature, therefore, this project will fill a gap in the literature. This project addresses critical issues with national significance about teacher preparation. In particular, this proposed project is well-positioned and needed to address issues raised by the National Research Council and in the PCAST Reports about the need for information related to the content of teacher education programs and the need for teachers with strong content and pedagogical knowledge for teaching algebra. This project will address the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM) by examining how closely aligned the current national teacher preparation programs are with the CCSSM. The findings shall have broad policy implications regarding teacher preparation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preparing high quality mathematics teachers is a national priority. Because algebra provides a foundation for further mathematics and serves as a gatekeeper for college and technical careers, policy makers are concerned about the lack of qualified algebra teachers. Yet, little has been known about how secondary mathematics teachers are prepared. The Preparing to Teach Algebra (PTA) project was designed to investigate opportunities that secondary mathematics teacher education (SMTE) programs provide their students to learn algebra, to learn to teach algebra, to learn the algebra described in the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics [CCSSM], and to learn about equity issues related to algebra.

PTA was a collaborative project involving researchers at Michigan State University and Purdue University. In 2012 researchers administered a survey to representatives of 400 colleges and universities; 128 valid responses were obtained from 44 states. The results illustrate the diversity and complexity of SMTE programs for initial licensure in the United States. The most common certification level offered was a combined middle/high school program (reported by 76% of the institutions); 30% reported a high school only program and 27% reported a middle grades only program. The number of graduates of SMTE programs for the three years prior to survey administration ranged from 0 to 55, with a median of five and mean of nine. About 75% of respondents reported a Baccalaureate program as their largest initial licensure program, and18% reported their largest program was a Post-baccalaureate program, with  the majority of these leading to a Master’s degree.

Respondents from middle/high school programs reported meeting the recommendations of the mathematics community described in the Mathematical Education of Teachers II [MET II] for the number of hours of mathematics required. The four most commonly required post-calculus courses reported were Linear Algebra, Abstract Algebra, Probability/Statistics, and Geometry. However, programs that prepared teachers for middle grades did not typically require students to take the Number Theory, History of Mathematics, or Mathematical Modeling courses suggested by MET II; both the middle school and the high school preparation programs generally failed to meet the recommended number of courses and/or semester-hours for courses designed for teachers to study K-12 school mathematics from an advanced perspective. Among baccalaureate programs, respondents reported greater opportunities to learn algebra than to learn to teach algebra, or to learn about equity issues in algebra or the algebra highlighted in CCSSM.  Among Post-baccalaureate programs, opportunities to learn to teach algebra were reported more frequently than the other types of opportunities to learn.

The lack of a systematic database of secondary mathematics teacher education programs not only made it difficult for researchers to create a representative sample, but also limits the ability of educators, prospective students, or school counselors to identify the most appropriate program for their research and/or academic interests.

PTA researchers also conducted case studies of five purposefully chosen SMTEs in five states. Four were Baccalaureate programs and one was a Post-baccalaureate program leading to initial licensure without a Master’s degree. Two were located in urban areas with diverse populations; the other three were in smaller cities or towns with majority White students. All were combined middle/high school preparation programs. Analysis of opportunities to learn algebra and to teach algebra in the case studies is ongoing. Reported opportunities to learn [OTL] about equity related to algebra were classified according to (a) Gutiérrez’s (2012) conception of equity as access, achievement, identity, and power, and (b) content-specificity (i.e., algebra-specific, mathematics-specific, and general). The mathematics- and algebra-specific Equity OTLs reported were most frequently related to issues of access and achievement, whereas the Equity OTLs reported in general education courses were mostly related to issues of power and identity. The two programs with more diverse populations reported a relatively greater emphasis on equity.

Maeda, Y., Newton, J. Alexander, V. G., & Senk S. L. (2014). Development of a national survey for secondary mathematics teacher education programs: Challenges and lessons learned. Assessment Update, 26(3), 5-6, 12-13.

Mintos, A., Hoffman, A., Kersey, A, Newton, J., & Smith, D. (Submitted for publication). Learning about issues of equity in secondary mathematics teacher education programs.

Newton, J., Maeda, Y., Alexander, V., & Senk, S. (2014). Recommendations from MET II: Investigating the alignment of secondary mathematics teacher education programs. Notices of the American Mathematical Society, 61(3), 292-295.
